title: The reason why Memes and Games are making fun of us Gameplay guys all the time.
body:
It's not because we write unnecessarily long balance essays that won't change anything 99% of the time anyway, no, it's because HOW a lot of us write them.

Instead of writing concerns in a constructive and civilized fashion, often times it's just a really angry shitpost that only conveys how angry someone is about something, most of the time without giving a potential fix for the problem at hand ( if it even exists ).

I think this is kind of sad. A lot of these angry posts are written by people who actually have a lot of game knowledge and valid concerns at their core, they are just presented in such an inappropriate manner that they are most likely not going to change anything anyway.

Imagine you are a dev, you work on the game full-time, do your best to make everything balanced and are eager to hear the community's concerns and to improve yourself. Instead of good advise on how to do that, everyone just tells you to fuck off and that everything you do is bad. Would you really listen to someone who does that? Who just cries at you and makes a scapegoat out of you instead of actually trying to help you with your job and giving you valid feedback?

The truth is, if any of the people who write these angry shitposts would somehow actually be hired to become a gameplay dev, after they did some changes they would most likely get exactly the same shitposts as a response, about how bad their changes are, how they don't know anything about the game and how they don't care about the community.

If you really want the devs to listen, be nice, do your research and be constructive. There is enough tilt and rage in-game already, no need to bring it over here aswell.

replies.body:
First off, I think it’s part of the job of a game developer to be aware and listen to player feedback in whatever form it takes. Just because someone is angry doesn’t mean they don’t have some good points, or that how they feel is invalid. I don’t think you have to be too concerned about hurting our feelings.

BUT, the thing about angry shitposts is that it’s lot more difficult to break down which parts are good feedback, and which parts are just emotional reactions. And that means that what may have been a valid argument gets lost in the assumptions, knee-jerk reactions, or waterfall of emotional responses. It’s a lot harder to justify taking an argument seriously when it doesn’t feel like the other party is doing so. 

I don’t think that’s a super great thing for us to do - as I said, just because someone writes an angry post doesn’t negate their point, but the truth is that digging through vitriol to find the nugget of good feedback can be challenging or emotionally draining. The main argument you want to make may get lost in the noise.

So, my advice, if you feel strongly about about champion balance, an item, a piece of music, or whatever, and you want to have a discussion about it, think about the core point you want to make, take a breath, break it down, and write it out in an organized, objective way. Try playing devil’s advocate to your own argument, think about the other perspective, test your assumptions. For developers, the most useful discussions come when someone talks through their thought process.

I work on videos here, and we have some guidelines we use when we’re looking for feedback on our projects. It’s not a perfect comparison, but I’ll share it here, if you’re interested.  


 1. Identify the “Why”
- So you don’t like the editing of this scene - great, but _why_ do you feel that way?
 2. Don’t be prescriptive.
- Identify the causes of problems, rather than demanding specific remedies.
- Pitching ideas/solutions is awesome, as well as providing examples as to why you feel the way you do.
 3. Be specific.  
- Detail is very helpful.
- “This Sucks” is not very helpful.


This doesn’t mean that every post that does these things will get a Riot response, but I can promise you that if I’m reading through the boards and see a thoughtful discussion, I will send it to a Rioter working on that thing. In my experience, those kinds of posts are much more likely to make their way around the office and get seen.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Calad,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=T2JNb3cm,comment-id=002d,timestamp=2017-03-16T02:28:47.396+0000)
>
> So, my advice, if you feel strongly about about champion balance, an item, a piece of music, or whatever, and you want to have a discussion about it, think about the core point you want to make, take a breath, break it down, and write it out in an organized, objective way. 

This **_DOES NOT WORK_** on a reddit style upvote/downvote system.

You need to clickbait and you need to rage, or people won't upvote your posts. Which means your post will be seen by 20 people instead of thousands (and probably zero reds).

It's an inherent flaw in your boards system. One time I posted the **_EXACT_** same thread 15 times over a span of a few months. The first 14 times, it got downvoted and lost into the abyss. The 15th time, I had finally figured out how to make it clickbaity enough to get upvotes and it was seen by thousands. I had to literally market my idea to the masses in order for it to get seen. I couldn't just write it in a coherent and objective way.

I think it depends on what your goals are. If you want to get THE MOST UPVOTES you're probably right, going simple and emotional will get you further.

But if you want to have a meaningful discussion or understand why a nerf/buff happened or actually affect change in League, I think you're more likely to find success by posting something more comprehensive and well-thought out.

But...there's definitely something in what you say. If you write a super long post and someone instantly scans it and downvotes it, it's less likely to rise and less likely to be seen by anyone, Riot included. I'm not sure exactly what the solution is here - if we as a community need be more aggressive about promoting thoughtful discussion over knee-jerk reactions, or if this an issue with the boards that Riot needs to try and solve. 

It's probably a bit of both?

Thanks for posting, this is actually really good feedback.

>If Riot wants to reduce toxicity and backlash from the community, you really ought to open more lines, and consistent lines, of communication with us. 

That also means stop hiding on the policed League Reddit where criticism is more often than not filtered out because it's deemed "anti-Riot" to make way for more esports drama and pro montages when the front page isn't just exclusively  LCS vomit from the games that day. 

Part of the reason Boards are so vitriolic, as has been mentioned throughout this thread, and I am guilty of this as well,  is that it's the only way it gets attention.  I could make an eloquent and thought-provoking post challenging Riot's philosophy, but it's not going to get anywhere for two reasons: 1, I'm honestly a cynical, grudge-bearing prick and have been my whole life so there's a lack of ability  from the start, and 2, because I'm pretty sure I'm not a well-known poster, it's going to be drowned out by everyone else, so it's a wasted effort. 

Another contributing factor is that every year, Riot claims they'll do better at communicating, and if they meant what they said and actually followed through with being more transparent than each previous year, by now we should have a live video feed of their department meetings.  Each year, the same exact thing happens - they make a copy-pasted apology for brick walling us, spend the first few months talking, then abandon ship and hardly ever show up again.  Every. Single. Year.  Y'know where they _do_ appear?  Reddit, and why wouldn't they?  It's a cesspool of esports spam and positivity because the mods hate it when people speak out against the benevolent rulers.  Anyone remember the East Coast servers movement where threads were being auto-deleted because they were "being an inconvenience to Riot?" 


Maybe the real League forums (us, not Reddit) wouldn't be such a toxic place if there was communication when some fuck-up or apparent careless balancing happens so Riot can see the other side of their perspective.  The issue with this is the white knights who's only purpose is to sprint to the rescue and cry away the "salty haters" who dare talk back to the reds.  Currently, there's less of it, but there was a long period between the end of season 5 and all throughout 6 where Riot seemed to _only_ listen to positive comments and praise, seeming to value "HAW HAW I LUV U RITO HAVE MUH BABBYZ!" over someone challenging their direction on an addition or change, where it's instantly brushed aside and ignored. For a recent example, remember Duskblade's announcement, and the thread was filled with warnings that giving a mini Zed ult to everyone was a terrible idea on top of the danger of ranged champions abusing it?  Gee, it's a good thing they were wro-...oh wait. 

The final part of this expands on the last paragraph; that people will too often associate a challenge with hate, since it's often difficult to match a tone with text when it's going against something, automatically making it negative.  Yesterday, Ghostcrawler answered some questions in a GDC topic, and again, people associate me challenging Riot's ideology with just senseless hate.  A similar thing happened [here](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/BXOezvo6-explain-yourself-riot?comment=0019) where he was describing Riot's hesitance on 10 bans, and I challenged him, and one of the first responses to that was "aw shit someone just smited riot" ...that...that wasn't the intent...but if everything going against Riot is seen as doing it out of hate or spite, then people need to stop being so damn sensitive, especially the boot lickers shielding Reds from any and all criticism.

I just flat-out disagree with you about the League subreddit not being critical. League and Riot get plenty of criticism there, some fair and some less so. I think the main reason more Rioters talk there is just because it's more familiar to them. It's something they log on every day anyway.

And I think you're right about the fact that Riot has been saying for a long time that we'll get better at communication, and it's totally reasonable to feel burned by that. However speaking as potentially biased party, [I'm](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner) [really](http://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/) [proud](https://engineering.riotgames.com/) [of](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueofriot/) [the](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/redtracker) [communications](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5U1Gcf8l8yY) [we've](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFwrySPCff8) [been](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/ppkM0ZAu-quick-gameplay-thoughts-march-14) [releasing](http://www.lolesports.com/en_US/articles/arena-home-of-the-na-lcs) [over](http://universe.leagueoflegends.com/en_US/) [the](http://askghostcrawler.tumblr.com/) [past](http://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/2017/03/ask-riot-champ-ideas-and-unexplored-regions/) [six](https://www.twitch.tv/leagueoflegends/videos/all) [months](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/XtVmFid3-patch-chat-with-the-playtest-team-75-aatrox-mini-update). From my perspective, it's more than we've done for a long time, and it comes because we're trying to invest in making it more of a priority. 

We almost covered communication in the recent Riot Pls video, but figured it was one of those things we'd rather try and show than tell.

Yes I won't disagree that communication recently has been much much better, and I'm hoping it continues this time, but I'll stand by my position against Reddit, especially when Riot converted their old forums into a Reddit clone, then walked away from it when the community didn't like it back to the real Reddit.  It also just looks pretty unprofessional to use third party sites to communicate rather than the official forums.

We use more than just reddit and boards to talk to players. 

And we care _a lot_ more about communicating with players than looking professional.

You care? Fine, why does Aatrox suck so much? Why is a Galio rework more important then Mordekaiser rework (just to clarify, Galio was always fine and Morde sucks)? Why Vanguard update instead of Diver update? Oh and if you care about your community then why did you not listen to people on the PBE saying that Aatrox changes suck?  I know this will probably be ignored, cuz who cares what a Silver shitlord like me says anyway, but fuck it, somebody should say it.

I think this is an example of the kind of emotional post that makes it difficult to engage because there’s a lot of assumptions being made, and it doesn’t feel like you really want answers as much as you want to vent. But what the hell, let me try anyway. 

> [{quoted}](name=Arkadije95,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=T2JNb3cm,comment-id=002d0001000000010000000000000002,timestamp=2017-03-16T17:40:05.143+0000)
>
> You care? Fine, why does Aatrox suck so much? 

The goals with the Aatrox mini-update were not specifically to buff or nerf him, but rather to get him into a place that [we felt he could be balanceable](http://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/2017/01/dev-state-of-champion-update-january-2017/). Another goal was to do something for a character we’ve historically neglected for a long time, rather than let him sit until we do a diver update at one point in the future.

> [{quoted}](name=Arkadije95,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=T2JNb3cm,comment-id=002d0001000000010000000000000002,timestamp=2017-03-16T17:40:05.143+0000)
>
>  Why is a Galio rework more important then Mordekaiser rework (just to clarify, Galio was always fine and Morde sucks)?

Just to clarify, that’s a huge assumption you’re making. I’m not sure the champion update team would agree with you. [Here’s why the team decided to focus on Galio.](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/champions-skins/champion-update/state-champion-update)

“Currently Galio has a lot of problems. His theme, gameplay, and art hasn’t aged very well at all. This gives us a pretty wide canvas to paint on and Galio will likely be our largest transformation to date. So what are our goals with Galio? With Galio we want to see if we can really deliver on a mid lane focused tank/mage , as we think that opens up a lot of interesting strategies (not that he has to be played exclusively mid of course).”

I think that if we’d decided to prioritize Morde instead of Galio, there would be plenty of players asking “Why is another Morde rework more important than a Galio rework?!” In this case, I trust the Champion Update team to determine their priorities. 
> [{quoted}](name=Arkadije95,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=T2JNb3cm,comment-id=002d0001000000010000000000000002,timestamp=2017-03-16T17:40:05.143+0000)
>
> Why Vanguard update instead of Diver update?

[Reav3 goes into why we decided to focus on Vanguards here. ](http://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/2017/01/dev-state-of-champion-update-january-2017/)

“As for unique identities, our Vanguards in particular are currently very similar to each other. They all are basically different versions of Amumu—they go in, do some AOE CC, then stand around doing ambient damage to the enemy team. One of our major goals will be to make the Vanguards we rework break this mold in new and exciting ways. We also want to take a real hard look at defensive items and how the entire roster (both tanks and non-tanks) engages with them. We want tanks to get a much greater benefit from tank items than other classes, so they can correctly play the role of being the tankiest champions in the game.”

[And there's a little conversation about why Vanguards instead of Divers on reddit here.](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/5ra6s4/state_of_champion_update_january_2017/dd5lon0/)

We’re still planning to work on Divers in the future. Something has to come first, and in this case, the team decided to prioritize Vanguards because they felt that Tank items are in need of a update. And those items have the potential to affect Divers as well, so it makes sense to me to work on Tanks first and then Divers.

> [{quoted}](name=Arkadije95,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=T2JNb3cm,comment-id=002d0001000000010000000000000002,timestamp=2017-03-16T17:40:05.143+0000)
>
> Oh and if you care about your community then why did you not listen to people on the PBE saying that Aatrox changes suck?

Balance is tricky. An hour of live gameplay gives us so much more data than we get internally, or from PBE. Ultimately, you have to try and balance a lot of different factors, get as close as you can, and react to how things land. In Aatrox’s case, he came out pretty weak, and [we even pushed a hotfix for him](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/Qa21ePAW-quick-gameplay-thoughts-march-9), rather than try and keep him waiting a full patch cycle.

"Aatrox looks like he's almost certainly too weak by a noticeable margin. We're looking at possible buffs, with a decent chance we hotfix at least some of them out. We would expect Aatrox to struggle somewhat as players adapt to new builds, the changed passive etc, it looks like his kit's just too weak as well though."

We will never get to a state where we can perfectly predict how balanced a change will be. Sometimes we will be right and sometimes we will be wrong. I think the more important thing is that we admit when we're wrong and try and make changes things quickly, which I feel we did here.

I understand, as do most companies, but it appears that you prioritize Reddit, that's what I'm getting at.  These forums have gone on weeks of drought before in gameplay, where Reddit was lively.  I'm saying that should be reversed since it's third party vs. the host site, where going back to Reddit, I'm able to make an account for free in less than 10 seconds with no prior League experience and it could be assumed that I'm a player...that's messed up.  At least on here, you can look up the people posting, see who they are, who they main, how long they've been playing, etc.  And maybe it's  that way _right now,_ but it wasn't in the past, and I'm asking if it could stay that way for the sake of "looking professional" even if you're not...it's a bit awkward trying to describe, but I hope you understand.

I've discussed something similar with a Rioter in the past on here. It was when they kept doing AMAs on Reddit instead of here. Important discussion points were being made over there as opposed to here, the official boards for the game. Then we got cross-posts onto the boards here giving occasional summaries of info that went out on Reddit. 

I argued that should be the other way around. My opinion was noted, but the response was largely "Rioters do this on their own time and they're free to use whatever platforms they want". I get that, but would still maintain that Riot should encourage use of their own boards first and foremost, but allow them to to still participate elsewhere.

Thank you dropping by! While you're on this subject, would you consider having a talk with the team working on Boards? I made a larger post [a little further below](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/T2JNb3cm-the-reason-why-memes-and-games-are-making-fun-of-us-gameplay-guys-all-the-time?comment=0017) that talks about this in more detail, but I think a large part of the issue with shitposts on Gameplay is structural: many people shitpost not necessarily because they're bad people, or even because they're really upset, but because the boards here unintentionally encourage them to do so. Problems like the widely abused upvote system, lack of appropriate report options and insufficient moderation are allowing much more noise to appear here than is necessary, drowning out many thoughtful posts and driving developers away from communicating here. This has also been an issue for quite some time, and it would be helpful for the Boards team to at least give their thoughts on the space's current state, and let us know what they've got in store.

Hey Teridax,

Thanks for linking this, I think you're well-spoken and make some good points. I will hold up my end of the bargain and share it around with some Rioters tomorrow. I'm not sure if we're ready to talk about potential changes we want to make to the boards yet, but I will make sure your post gets seen.

Thank you so much for the response! This means a lot to me, and while I imagine Riot reads much more content on Boards than we players think, having that confirmation from a red post, no matter the size, makes a whole world of difference. Best of luck on your future work. :)

We need to pin this Rioter response to the top of the gameplay boards along with that Bill Nye "Consider the following" post.

You see, I wish we had more of this right here. The simple fact that you stopped by and acknowledged the post, and contributed to the discussion. Obviously this can't be done with every post, but I personally feel like it isn't done enough.

I feel like it would go a long way if we, the players, knew that you guys were at least listening. 

You said occasionally that if you see something worthy of passing on to somebody in the office who takes care of that problem, then you do so. Have you ever just stopped, before you forwarded the post, and mentioned to the poster, "hey, I really thought your post was laid out well, and I wanted to let you know I sent it to X,Y,Z."

Imagine how encouraging that would be if that poster realized, "hey, maybe this problem will get solved, or I know I can at least expect some feedback."

Rather than what I feel we struggle with on a daily basis. "Why doesn't riot ever listen to the players?" Or, "why does it feel like Riot doesn't even play their own game."

I own a local business in my city, and my staff and I always have a line of communication open. It's rare something happens without me knowing about it. If I didn't encourage my staff to communicate with me openly and honestly about anything, I can tell you for a fact, I would have gone out of business very quickly.

 I also encourage my clients to maintain lines of communication after their appointments, I personally email every client each and every time we do a job for them asking for feedback. I also follow up with a phone call the next day to make sure they got the email.

You know what has come out of that extra effort on my part? 5 star reviews. 90% of my business is referrals and word of mouth from someone passing along my business card telling their friends and family, "hey, you ought to call this guy, he will take great care of you."

If Riot wants to reduce toxicity and backlash from the community, you really ought to open more lines, and consistent lines, of communication with us. Communication is a two-way street. If you tell us, "here's why we made this decision and that's the way it's going to be." We are going to raise a stink. On the flip side of the coin, if you ask us before hand, "hey, we are considering doing this, what do you guys think?" And have an actual discussion with us, I feel like it would be better for everyone.

Just my 2 cents.

But there is *one* problem with your three criteria, and it lies in the upvote-downvote system in place.
The more specific you go, the easier it is to get downvoted. A lot of posts get upvoted not only because it appeals to emotion, but because vague leaves less to disagree and specific leaves a lot to disagree with. In turn, the post gets buried and never seen.


A very simple example would be a post saying healing and shielding is overtuned

Saying that healing and shielding is OP and leaving with an insult to Riot doesn't insult anyone but Riot so very few people would downvote.

Saying that healing and shielding can be potentially OP because Redemption did ridiculously large amounts at early levels, and was made to compete with damage which is already off the charts from power creep, and that it should be nerfed because when damage creep is finally addressed it'll lead to ridiculously broken amounts of damage mitigation leaves a lot of points to disagree with. People will downvote out of impulse and a knee-jerk reaction to the idea that an item they like is OP, that damage creep is a problem when they like oneshotting, or that a meta revolving around redemption would be bad.

What's even worse is peer pressure that no one likes to admit to, a -1 post is likely to go to -10, rather than back to 1 or even 0. People who would agree to the post end up not voting and asking themselves what *they* missed that makes everyone downvote, rather than upvoting because they agree.

The solution would be to remove the upvote downvote system, or to change it somehow to allow people to agree to varying degrees. Maybe each paragraph has its own scoring? Even then I'd make the numbers hidden and definitely not visible at least until after the upvote or downvote has been given. More importantly there needs to be a sort of nudge or encouragement to go through the entire post, and upvote for agreeing with a few things, not downvote for disagreeing with a few things.

This is all true, and I agree that Gameplay will never be as productive as it could be with its current atmosphere. However, I don't think this is something that the userbase here will simply understand and adapt to, because Gameplay's toxicity comes from its very structure. One of the reasons shitposts are so popular, for example, is because they often get upvoted a ton, whereas more constructive posts, especially posts that make suggestions, get downvoted into obscurity before they get a real chance, simply because one or a few people saw the thread and instinctively disagreed with one thing that was said out of many. On top of this, the Gameplay boards are so poorly curated and moderated that there is very little overall quality control, allowing the cheap, easy and useless posts to overtake the more thoughtful ones. Riot's general lack of participation may be a result of Gameplay's toxic atmosphere, but it's also a vicious cycle, since the lack of communication on here simply generates more frustration overall.

The thing is, while the OP is excellent and useful, this is not the first time a thread like this has been made. If you simply tell Gameplay they're being toxic and that they need to change, they're not going to care, not just because they likely know already, but because their toxicity comes from improper incentives and moderation: with its current structure, Gameplay is pushing people to make low-effort posts, and away from constructive discussion, and if that doesn't change, the boards will not change. This is obviously not what Riot intended, but it's also something their forum team has made no real effort to rectify in all these years. It's silly, because it's also likely what caused Riot's communication channels to move to everywhere _but_ Gameplay: we now have a Dev Corner where only Rioters can post, the Nexus feed where the devs mostly talk _at_ the playerbase, rather than _with_ them, and then we have Reddit and ask.fm, which allow for two-way communication, but are unaffiliated with League's official site and tend to lead to only sporadic dev interaction. Riot should have a vested interest in bringing Gameplay up to far better standards, as it would allow them to centralize a lot of their communications, and achieve a much more useful and functional level of interaction with their players, while collecting much higher-quality feedback.
